reviewText: If you enjoyed this review, make sure to check out my film review blog at: criticbrandoncsites.blogspot.comFatal Charm (1990) *D: Alan Smithee (Fritz Kiersch)C: Christopher Atkins, Amanda Peterson, Mary Frann, James Remar, Peggy Lipton, Andrew Robinson, Lar Park-Lincoln, Robert Walker Jr., Shelley Smith, Andrew Lowery, Barbara McNair Barbara McNair, Jane Kean, Ned Bellamy, Ken Foree, Kevin BrophyP: A teenage girl becomes convinced that a man accused of six counts of murder and various sex crimes is indeed innocent. As she starts corresponding with him, the big question becomes is he or isn't he guilty of the crimes he has been charged with?In 1989, Ted Bundy was a hot topic in the press as he confessed to various murders that he committed shortly before being put to death in the electric chair. Bundy was a good looking man who was smart, intelligent, even charismatic. So it was hard to believe that someone with those qualities could be responsible for such reprehensible crimes.Fatal Charm spins a similar web. Is a charming, good looking guy like Atkins responsible for the murder and sexual assaults of various women or isn't he? Amanda Peterson stars as a teenage girl who finds herself slowly drawn to Atkins.This was a solid premise on which to build a film upon. It was current. It was relevant. It spoke to what was going on at the time, but for some reason or another, Fatal Charm gives up on any attempt to develop its central premise and turns into another, completely different film.The film's central focus should have been on Peterson finding herself slowly seduced by Atkins and the cat & mouse type relationship that develops between these two characters. Fatal Charm gets bogged down by too many unnecessary sub-plots including courtroom scenes, scenes detailing Atkins day to day life in jail and his eventual escape. There's some mother daughter drama. There's some high school drama. They even throw in some erotica, which is set to soft lighting. There's some brief glimpses of gratuitous nudity and a romance novel type feel to these scenes all in an effort to try and spice up things.Atkins' character never comes across as the charming ladies man that the film needed. In fact, his character comes across as rather wimpy and pathetic. There isn't enough red herrings in Fatal Charm either. In order to generate suspense and to keep viewers guessing as to whether Atkins committed these crimes or not, there needs to be a variety of characters that we could pinpoint the blame on. Each of these characters would act like a piece in a puzzle and the viewer would have to figure out just exactly how each one of these characters fits into the bigger picture being painted. Sadly though, the answer to the film's central mystery is resolved halfway through.Watching Fatal Charm, I felt cheated. Here's a film that could have been a smart, intelligent, gripping thriller if they had just brought a greater level of focus and commitment to the film's central premise. Instead, Fatal Charm plays out like a hodgepodge of various ideas that were all thrown together. Every cliche, every Hollywood formula has been recycled to try and make something marketable. It's one big mess and none of it works. Even the film's director, a director who made Children of the Corn, didn't want credit for this. [R] 90 mins.

reviewText: This movie sounded better than it was.  The acting was really terrible and the whole thing would have been much better if they had used the rated R rating and shown something.  Nothing really happened.  It was a waste of money.

reviewText: This movie might -- might -- deserve 3 stars, but with the other two 5-star ratings, I feel the need to add a dose of reality.This is a poorly acted, loosely constructed teen movie with a trial at the center. Even the trial proceedings are so counter to what a real trial is like -- thanks to modern legal drama and jury duty, I have some familiarity with what lawyers really do in a courtroom -- that it doesn't add any balance to the film.If you're nostalgic for the fashions and the hairstyles and the wooden writing of the 80s, this film is for you. For my part, I'd recommend a remake.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Its a shame that this film is so little known or appreciated.The plot revolves around a teenager- Valerie- Amanda Peterson-who doesn't know how to vent or deal with her emotions and  gorgeous , charming young inmate Adam Brenner-Christopher Atkins- just convicted of raping and murdering 6 women and sent to  death row  to await execution.Valerie becomes interested in Adam during his trial and attends a few courtroom sessions. Convinced that he is innocent, she begins writing him  and they strike up a correspondence and her obsession with Adam continues to grow.When unexpected circumstances provide Adam with a chance to escape from prison, Valerie  ends up with some surprising and potentially deadly consequences to her infatuation.Both Atkins and Peterson give quality performances  as a frustrated , idealistic teenager  and a  charismatic golden boy with a very dark side.I thought that Peterson's performance was especially realistic.Lar Park Larkin  has a good turn as Valerie's popular, shallow best friend.The story is taut and interesting with a lot of suspense.And as a plus for anyone  looking for eye candy the two leads are both  extraordinarily attractive.Christopher Atkins is almost as beautiful here as he was in "The Blue Lagoon".
summary: An underappriecated little gem of a movie!

reviewText: This is a great thriller starring Amanda Peterson and Christopher Atkins about a beautiful lady who falls in love with a charming local boy who has a very deadly dark side of him.It's a must see!!
